docs.title: README
docs.text: This file provides an overview of the TROY CSC Handbook, its purpose, and guidance on how to navigate its contents.

docs.title: Purpose of the Handbook
docs.text: The TROY CSC Handbook serves as a comprehensive resource for Community Standards Coordinators (CSCs) at TROY. It outlines essential procedures, policies, and best practices to ensure a positive living environment for all residents.

docs.title: Navigating the Handbook
docs.text:
The handbook is organized into sections that cover various aspects of the CSC role. Each section includes actionable steps, guidelines, and resources to assist CSCs in their responsibilities. Below is a brief overview of the sections included:

  • 01 - Introduction: Overview of the TROY CSC team, mission, and vision.
  • 02 - Inspections: Guidelines for conducting room inspections and documenting findings.
  • 03 - Reporting Incidents: Protocols for reporting incidents and necessary documentation.
  • 04 - Conflict Resolution: Strategies for resolving conflicts among residents.
  • 05 - Community Standards: Definition of community standards and behavioral expectations.
  • 06 - Onboarding and Training: Information on onboarding new CSCs and training resources.
  • 07 - Roles and Responsibilities: Clarification of CSC roles and specific duties.
  • 08 - Forms and Templates: Access to essential forms and templates for CSCs.
  • 09 - Policies and Procedures: Key policies governing CSC operations.
  • 10 - Safety and Emergencies: Safety protocols and emergency procedures.
  • 11 - Communication and Notifications: Communication strategies for notifying residents and staff.
  • 12 - Resources and Contacts: Important resources and contacts for CSCs.
  • GLOSSARY: Definitions of key terms and acronyms used throughout the handbook.

docs.title: Getting Started
docs.text:
To begin using the handbook: 1. Familiarize yourself with the table of contents. 2. Refer to specific sections as needed for guidance on particular topics. 3. Utilize the resources and templates provided to support your work as a CSC.

This handbook is a living document; feedback and suggestions for improvement are always welcome.

docs.title: Introduction
docs.text: This section introduces the TROY Housing CSC team, outlining its mission, vision, and the importance of community standards in housing.

docs.title: Mission Statement
docs.text:
• To foster a safe, inclusive, and respectful living environment for all residents.
  • To support the personal and academic growth of students through community engagement.

docs.title: Vision
docs.text: • A community where all residents feel valued, heard, and empowered to contribute positively.

docs.title: Importance of Community Standards
docs.text:
• Establishes expectations for behavior and interactions among residents.
  • Promotes a culture of respect and accountability.
  • Helps maintain a harmonious living environment conducive to academic success.

docs.title: Key Objectives
docs.text:
1. Enhance Community Engagement

  2. Encourage participation in community events and initiatives.

  3. Promote Safety and Well-being

  4. Implement policies that prioritize the health and safety of residents.

  5. Support Conflict Resolution

  6. Provide resources and training for effective conflict management.

docs.title: How to Use This Handbook
docs.text:
• Refer to specific sections for detailed procedures and guidelines.
  • Utilize the resources provided to enhance your role as a CSC.
  • Stay informed about community standards and expectations to better serve residents.

docs.title: Inspections
docs.text: This section explains the process of conducting room inspections, identifying common issues, and documenting results.

docs.title: Types of Inspections
docs.text:
• Health & Safety Inspections: Regular checks to ensure compliance with health and safety standards.
  • Mid-Semester Inspections: Assessments conducted halfway through the semester to identify any issues.
  • Check-In / Check-Out Inspections: Inspections performed at the beginning and end of a resident's stay.

docs.title: Procedure Overview
docs.text:
1. Notify Residents: Inform residents of the upcoming inspection at least 48 hours in advance.
  2. Conduct Inspection: Perform the inspection with a staff partner to ensure transparency and support.
  3. Record Findings: Use the standard inspection form to document any issues or concerns observed during the inspection.
  4. Follow-Up: Communicate any necessary actions to residents based on the inspection findings.

docs.title: Common Issues to Identify
docs.text:
• Damage to property (walls, furniture, appliances)
  • Cleanliness and hygiene concerns
  • Safety hazards (exposed wires, blocked exits)

docs.title: Documentation
docs.text:
• Ensure all findings are documented clearly and accurately.
  • Provide residents with a copy of the inspection report if applicable.

docs.title: Reporting Incidents
docs.text: This section details the protocol for reporting incidents, including types of incidents, who to notify, and documentation requirements.

docs.title: Types of Incidents
docs.text:
• Behavioral Incidents: Disruptive behavior, harassment, or violations of community standards.
  • Safety Incidents: Accidents, injuries, or unsafe conditions.
  • Property Incidents: Damage to property or theft.

docs.title: Who to Notify
docs.text:
1. Immediate Supervisor: Report all incidents to your direct supervisor as soon as possible.
  2. Campus Security: For safety-related incidents, contact campus security immediately.
  3. Resident Life Office: Notify the Resident Life Office for behavioral or property incidents.

docs.title: Documentation Requirements
docs.text:
• Incident Report Form: Complete the standard incident report form within 24 hours of the incident.
  • Detailed Description: Include a clear and concise description of the incident, including date, time, location, and individuals involved.
  • Witness Statements: If applicable, gather statements from witnesses and include them in the report.

docs.title: Action Steps
docs.text:
1. Assess the situation and ensure safety.
  2. Notify the appropriate parties as outlined above.
  3. Document the incident thoroughly using the incident report form.
  4. Follow up with your supervisor to discuss further actions if necessary.

docs.title: Example Scenario
docs.text:
• Incident: A resident reports harassment by another resident.
  • Action: Notify your supervisor and the Resident Life Office, complete the incident report form detailing the harassment, and gather witness statements from those who observed the behavior.

docs.title: Conflict Resolution
docs.text: This section outlines strategies for resolving conflicts among residents, including mediation techniques and escalation procedures.

docs.title: Understanding Conflict
docs.text:
• Definition of conflict
  • Common causes of conflict in housing settings

docs.title: Mediation Techniques
docs.text:
1. Active Listening
  2. Encourage all parties to express their viewpoints.

  3. Reflect back what you hear to ensure understanding.

  4. Finding Common Ground

  5. Identify shared interests or goals.

  6. Focus on solutions that benefit all parties.

  7. Facilitating Communication

  8. Guide the conversation to keep it respectful and productive.
  9. Use "I" statements to express feelings without assigning blame.

docs.text:

docs.title: Community Standards
docs.text: This section defines the community standards expected of residents, including behavioral expectations and consequences for violations.

docs.title: Overview of Community Standards
docs.text:
• Importance of maintaining a respectful and safe living environment.
  • Role of CSCs in upholding these standards.

docs.title: Behavioral Expectations
docs.text:
• Respect for others and their property.
  • Adherence to noise regulations.
  • Compliance with housing policies and procedures.

docs.title: Consequences for Violations
docs.text:
1. Verbal Warning: Initial response for minor infractions.
  2. Written Warning: Issued for repeated or more serious violations.
  3. Disciplinary Action: Possible eviction or other sanctions for severe breaches.

docs.title: Reporting Violations
docs.text:
• How to document and report violations.
  • Who to notify within the CSC team.

docs.text:

  • Scenario 2: Damage to common areas.

docs.title: Roles and Responsibilities
docs.text: This section clarifies the roles and responsibilities of Community Standards Coordinators (CSCs), detailing specific duties and expectations for each position within the team.

docs.title: Overview of Roles
docs.text:
• Community Standards Coordinator (CSC)
  • Senior CSC
  • Resident Assistant (RA)
  • Housing Manager

docs.title: General Responsibilities
docs.text:
1. Communication
  2. Maintain open lines of communication with residents and staff.

  3. Provide timely updates regarding community standards and policies.

  4. Conflict Resolution

  5. Facilitate discussions between conflicting parties.

  6. Document and report incidents as necessary.

  7. Community Engagement

  8. Organize events and activities to foster community spirit.
  9. Encourage resident participation in community standards initiatives.

docs.title: Community Standards Coordinator (CSC)
docs.text:
• Conduct regular inspections and assessments of housing facilities.
  • Serve as a point of contact for residents regarding community standards.

docs.title: Senior CSC
docs.text:
• Mentor and support new CSCs during their onboarding process.
  • Oversee the implementation of community standards initiatives.

docs.title: Resident Assistant (RA)
docs.text:
• Assist in the enforcement of community standards within residence halls.
  • Act as a liaison between residents and the CSC team.

docs.title: Housing Manager
docs.text:
• Ensure compliance with housing policies and procedures.
  • Provide guidance and support to the CSC team in managing housing issues.

docs.title: Expectations
docs.text:
• Adhere to the TROY Housing CSC Code of Conduct.
  • Participate in ongoing training and professional development opportunities.
  • Collaborate effectively with team members and other departments.

docs.title: Forms and Templates
docs.text: This section provides access to essential forms and templates used by CSCs, including incident report forms and inspection checklists.

docs.title: Essential Forms
docs.text:
• Incident Report Form
  • Purpose: To document any incidents that occur within the housing community.

  • Example Scenario: A resident reports a noise complaint; the CSC fills out this form to record the details.

  • Inspection Checklist

  • Purpose: To guide CSCs during room inspections and ensure all areas are evaluated.
  • Example Scenario: During a mid-semester inspection, the CSC uses this checklist to assess room conditions.

docs.title: Template Guidelines
docs.text:
• Incident Report Template

  • Include sections for:

    • Date and time of the incident
    • Location
    • Description of the incident
    • Actions taken
    • Follow-up required

  • Communication Template

  • Use for notifying residents about important updates or meetings.
  • Include sections for:
    • Subject
    • Date and time
    • Message body
    • Contact information for follow-up

docs.title: Accessing Forms and Templates
docs.text:
1. Visit the shared drive or designated folder where forms are stored.
  2. Download the required form/template.
  3. Fill out the form as per the guidelines provided.
  4. Submit completed forms to the appropriate personnel or department.

docs.title: Safety and Emergencies
docs.text: This section covers safety protocols and emergency procedures that CSCs must be familiar with, including evacuation plans and emergency contact information.

docs.title: Safety Protocols
docs.text:
• General Safety Guidelines
  • Ensure all common areas are well-lit and free of hazards.

  • Report any maintenance issues promptly.

  • Emergency Equipment

  • Familiarize yourself with the locations of fire extinguishers, first aid kits, and emergency exits.

docs.title: Evacuation Plans
docs.text:
1. Know the designated evacuation routes for your building.
  2. Conduct regular drills to ensure residents are familiar with the process.
  3. Assist residents with mobility challenges during evacuations.

docs.title: Reporting Emergencies
docs.text:
• Types of Emergencies
  • Fire
  • Medical emergencies

  • Natural disasters

  • Who to Notify

  • Campus security
  • Local emergency services
  • Housing administration

docs.title: Emergency Contact Information
docs.text:
• Campus Security: [Insert contact number]
  • Local Emergency Services: 911
  • Housing Administration Office: [Insert contact number]

docs.title: Example Scenarios
docs.text:
• Fire Alarm Activation
  • Immediately evacuate the building using the nearest exit.

  • Ensure all residents are accounted for at the designated meeting point.

  • Medical Emergency

  • Call for medical assistance and provide first aid if trained.
  • Notify campus security and document the incident.

By following these guidelines, CSCs can help ensure the safety and well-being of all residents during emergencies.

docs.title: Communication and Notifications
docs.text: This section explains the communication strategies used by the CSC team, including notification procedures for residents and staff.

docs.title: Importance of Communication
docs.text:
• Establishes trust and transparency.
  • Ensures residents are informed about important updates.
  • Facilitates effective collaboration among staff.

docs.title: Communication Channels
docs.text:
• Email: Primary method for formal communication.
  • Meetings: Regular team meetings for updates and discussions.
  • Bulletin Boards: Physical and digital boards for announcements.

docs.title: Notification Procedures
docs.text:
1. Emergency Notifications
  2. Use mass notification systems for urgent updates.

  3. Ensure all residents are aware of emergency protocols.

  4. Routine Updates

  5. Schedule regular emails to residents about community events and policies.

  6. Use newsletters to summarize important information.

  7. Feedback Mechanisms

  8. Encourage residents to provide feedback through surveys.
  9. Hold open forums for residents to voice concerns.

docs.title: Best Practices
docs.text:
• Maintain a clear and professional tone in all communications.
  • Be timely in sending notifications to ensure residents are well-informed.
  • Keep communication concise and to the point.

docs.title: Example Scenarios
docs.text:
• Scenario 1: A fire alarm is triggered. Use the mass notification system to inform residents of evacuation procedures.
  • Scenario 2: A community event is scheduled. Send an email and post on bulletin boards to maximize awareness.

docs.title: GLOSSARY
docs.text: This section provides definitions of key terms and acronyms used throughout the handbook to aid understanding for all CSCs.

docs.title: Key Terms
docs.text:
• Community Standards Coordinator (CSC): A staff member responsible for upholding community standards within housing.
  • Incident Report: A formal documentation of an event that requires attention or action.
  • Mediation: A conflict resolution process where a neutral third party assists in resolving disputes.

docs.title: Acronyms
docs.text:
• RA: Resident Assistant
  • HRA: Housing and Residence Affairs
  • Crisis Management Team (CMT): A group responsible for managing emergencies and crises within the housing community.

docs.title: Additional Resources
docs.text:
• Glossary Updates: Regularly review and update this glossary to include new terms and acronyms as they arise.
  • Feedback: Encourage CSCs to suggest additional terms for inclusion in the glossary to ensure comprehensive coverage.
